Key Match Events: Giorgi Mamardashvili made as many saves (eight) by half-time as any other goalkeeper has in an entire match at Euro 2024 so far
Georges Mikautadze confidently slotted home to score the latest first-half goal – clocked at 48:20 – in European Championship history
Patrik Schick scored the equalizer with his seventh attempt of the game
Pre-Game Insights: Georgia are at Euro 2024 as complete outsiders, knowing that they might not have all that many opportunities to celebrate
Czech Republic flew out of the traps like a side who knew how big an opportunity this was – facing the lowest-ranked side in the tournament
The tournament minnows struggled to withstand the relentless attacks from Czech Republic
Georgia's resilience paid off, leading to a historic first point at a major international tournament as an independent nation
Post-Match Reflections: Giorgi Mamardashvili made 11 saves for Georgia in this match, which is the most by any goalkeeper in a single Euro 2024 match
Despite facing tournament highs for shots (27), shots on target (12) and xG (3.1), Georgia earned a historic first point at a major international tournament as an independent nation
Saba Lobjanidze missed a golden chance with the very last kick of the game after Georgia made a rare break up the field
Miscellaneous Highlights: Czech Republic recorded 12 shots on target against Georgia; the most by a team who failed to win the match at the UEFA European Championship on record (since 1980)
Patrik Schick is now Czechia’s top scorer at the UEFA European Championship, moving ahead of Milan Baros (5) with his sixth goal in the competition today
Georges Mikautadze became the sixth player to score both of his nation’s first two goals at the UEFA European Championship, and first since Andriy Shevchenko in 2012 for Ukraine
Others: Nine yellow cards were handed out in the game between Georgia (4) and Czechia (5); the most in a match at the UEFA European Championship since the 2016 final between France and Portugal (10)
